{{Infobox film | name = Atlas Shrugged: Part II | image = Poster for film "Atlas Shrugged Part II" (2012).png | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[John Putch]] | producer = {{Plainlist | * Harmon Kaslow * [[John Aglialoro]] * Jeff Freilich }} | screenplay = {{Plainlist | * Duke Sandefur * [[Brian Patrick O'Toole]] * [[Duncan Scott (director)|Duncan Scott]] }} | based on = {{Based on|''[[Atlas Shrugged]]''|[[Ayn Rand]]}} | starring = {{Plainlist | * [[Samantha Mathis]] * [[Jason Beghe]] * [[Esai Morales]] * [[Patrick Fabian]] * [[Kim Rhodes]] * [[Richard T. Jones]] * [[D.B. Sweeney]] }} | music = {{Plainlist | *[[Chris Bacon (composer)|Chris P. Bacon]] *Ash Brown *Gregg Benedict}}
| cinematography = Ross Berryman | editing = John Gilbert | studio = Either Or Productions | distributor = Atlas Distribution Company | released = {{Film date|2012|10|12}} | runtime = 112 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $10 million<ref name="WSJ">{{cite web |last=Steinberg |first=Don |title='Atlas Shrugged' Film Banks on Election Fever |url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10000872396390444592404578032291709944404 |publisher=''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' |date=October 5, 2012 |accessdate=November 9, 2012}}</ref> | gross = $3,336,053<ref name="mojo">{{cite web |title= Atlas Shrugged: Part II |url= http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=atlasshruggedpart2.htm |publisher= Amazon.com | work = [[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=December 16, 2012}}</ref> }} '''''Atlas Shrugged: Part II''''' (or '''''Atlas Shrugged II: The Strike'''''<ref>{{cite web |date=October 14, 2012 |first=Sheri |last=Linden |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-atlas-shrugged-20121015,0,3134211.story |title='Atlas Shrugged Part II: The Strike' blandly mediocre |publisher=''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' |accessdate=June 24, 2013}}</ref>) is a film based on the novel ''[[Atlas Shrugged]]'' by [[Ayn Rand]]. It is the second installment in the [[Atlas Shrugged (film series)|''Atlas Shrugged'' film series]] and the first [[sequel]] to the 2011 film ''[[Atlas Shrugged: Part I]]'', continuing the story where its predecessor left off.<ref name=LA20120202>{{cite web |title='Atlas Shrugged Part 2' to start production in April |first=Rebecca |last=Keegan |publisher=''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' |date=February 2, 2012 |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/movies/2012/02/atlas-shrugged-part-2-shooting-april.html |accessdate=June 24, 2013}}</ref>
The film was released on October 12, 2012.
==Plot== [[Dagny Taggart]] pilots an airplane in pursuit of another plane. Dagny asks herself, "Who is [[John Galt]]?" before apparently crashing into a mountainside.
Nine months earlier, Dagny is trying to understand the abandoned prototype of an advanced motor she and her lover [[Hank Rearden]] have found. Scientists across the country have been disappearing under mysterious circumstances, but Dagny is able to locate Quentin Daniels, who agrees to help from an abandoned laboratory in [[Utah]].
Dagny's brother [[James Taggart (Atlas Shrugged)|James Taggart]], president of the family [[railroad]] company, meets store clerk Cherryl Brooks and brings her to see a renowned pianist, who disappears during his performance, leaving a note asking, "Who is John Galt?" Later, at James and Cherryl's wedding, Dagny's friend [[Francisco d'Anconia]] argues with other guests about whether money is evil, and secretly informs Rearden about devastating explosions at his [[Copper extraction|copper mine]]—the next day. Rearden spends the night with Dagny. Later, he is confronted about the affair by his wife Lillian, but when he offers a divorce she declines, in order to maintain her position in society.
Rearden sells his advanced Rearden Metal to Ken Danagger's [[coal mining]] company, but refuses to sell it to the [[Federal government of the United States|federal government]], in defiance of the newly enacted "Fair Share" law that forces businesses to sell to all buyers. The two are charged under the law. Dagny barges into Danagger's office, realizes that he too is about to disappear, and understands that she is close to understanding the force behind the disappearances. At trial, Rearden defends [[Individualism|individual freedom]] and the pursuit of profit, and is given only a token penalty by the court, which fears turning him into a martyr. The government announces "Directive 10-289", which freezes employment and production and requires that all patents be gifted to the government. Rearden defies this decree as well, but relents when he is blackmailed with photos of himself and Dagny that would damage Dagny's reputation.
When Dagny hears about Rearden's "gift" and her brother's complicity, she quits the railroad. During her absence, a Taggart Transcontinental train collides with a military train in a tunnel, due largely to political pressure by a passenger and human error by Dagny's poorly trained replacement. This impels Dagny back to her job. D'Anconia tries to dissuade her from returning, as he had earlier tried to talk Rearden into leaving his business, but she returns anyway.
Dagny takes a train to [[Colorado]] to show her faith in the railway, but its engine fails. The repair technician used to work for 20th Century Motor Company, which produced the motor Dagny found. He tells Dagny how the [[From each according to his ability, to each according to his needs|need-based]] reward system in his company failed, and his coworker John Galt left the company vowing to "stop the motor of the world." Dagny calls Daniels, who tells her that he is quitting. Dagny buys a small airplane and flies to [[Utah]] to try to dissuade him, but as she is landing, she sees him get into a plane on the airstrip.
After a pursuit in the air—the opening scene of the film—Dagny's plane crashes in a valley hidden by [[stealth technology]]. A wounded Dagny Taggart crawls to the edge of her crashed plane, where she is greeted by John Galt.
==Cast== {{see also|List of Atlas Shrugged characters}} * [[Samantha Mathis]] as Dagny Taggart * [[Jason Beghe]] as Henry Rearden * [[Esai Morales]] as Francisco d'Anconia * [[Patrick Fabian]] as James Taggart * [[Kim Rhodes]] as Lillian Rearden * [[Richard T. Jones]] as Eddie Willers * [[D.B. Sweeney]] as John Galt * [[Paul McCrane]] as Wesley Mouch * [[John Rubinstein]] as Dr. Floyd Ferris * [[Robert Picardo]] as Dr. Robert Stadler * [[Ray Wise]] as Head of State Thompson * [[Diedrich Bader]] as Quentin Daniels * [[Bug Hall]] as Leonard Small * [[Arye Gross]] as Ken Danagger * [[Michael Gross (actor)|Michael Gross]] as Ted 'Buzz' Killman * [[Rex Linn]] as Kip Chalmers * [[Larisa Oleynik]] as Cherryl Brooks * [[Thomas F. Wilson]] as Robert Collins * [[Raymond Teller|Teller]] as Laughlin * [[Sean Hannity]] as himself<ref name="politicoii">{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/click/2012/09/hannity-to-debut-in-atlas-shrugged-part-ii-134631.html |title=Hannity to debut in 'Atlas Shrugged: Part II |publisher=Politico.Com |date=August 31, 2012 |accessdate=October 13, 2012}}</ref> * [[Juan Williams]] as himself<ref name="politicoii" /> * [[Bob Beckel]] as himself<ref name="politicoii" /> * [[Tamara Holder]] as herself<ref name="politicoii" />
==Production== The producers intended to finance ''Part II'' using profits from ''[[Atlas Shrugged: Part I]]''. When that film failed to generate a profit, a private debt sale in early 2012 raised $16 million of the $25 million the producers sought,<ref>{{cite web |title='Atlas Shrugged: Part 2' movie funded |first=Peter |last=Key |work=[[Philadelphia Business Journal]] |date=February 6, 2012 |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/philadelphia/blog/peter-key/2012/02/atlas-shrugged-part-2-movie-on-the-way.html |accessdate=June 24, 2013}}</ref> enabling a budget larger than that of the first film. There is some confusion about the relative size of the budget for the first two movies. The part 2 production budget was around $10 million and the marketing budget around $10 million, between 2010 and 2012. During the first movie a total of less than $20 million were spent over the course of the preceding 18 years. Hence, more was spent directly on producing the 2nd movie. The production company announced that Part 2 would be released to coincide with the U.S. general election season in fall 2012.<ref name="LA20120202" />
Duncan Scott, who in 1986 was responsible for creating a new, re-edited version of the [[We the Living (film)|1942 Italian film adaptation]] of Ayn Rand's novel ''[[We the Living]]'' with English subtitles, joined the production team.<ref>{{cite web |first=Paul |last=Bond |title='Atlas Shrugged Part 2' Timed to Hit Screens Just Before Presidential Election (Video) |url= http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/atlas-shrugged-part-2-prduction-april-286633 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=February 2, 2012 |accessdate=February 2, 2012}}</ref>
The name of the production company for the second film, Either Or Productions, LLC, is taken from the title Rand gave to the middle section of her novel. An April press release stated the name of the film as ''Atlas Shrugged, Part 2: Either Or.''<ref name="atlas20120402" />
[[Principal photography]] began on April 2, 2012 with an all-new cast, including [[Samantha Mathis]] as the heroine [[Dagny Taggart]], [[Jason Beghe]] as the industrialist [[Henry Rearden]], and [[Esai Morales]] as the playboy [[Francisco d'Anconia]].<ref name="atlas20120402">{{cite web |first=Scott |last=DeSapio |url= http://blog.atlasshruggedmovie.com/2012/04/atlas-shrugged-part-2-begins-principal.html |title=Atlas Shrugged Part 2 Begins Principal Photography |publisher=Official Atlas Shrugged Movie Blog |date=April 2, 2012 |accessdate=January 28, 2013}}</ref> Producer John Aglialoro has implied that hiring the cast of Part I for the sequel exceeded the movie's budget, saying "it's hard to lock people down", and also noting that [[Taylor Schilling]], the actress who played Dagny in Part I, is "a bona fide movie star now".<ref>{{cite web |title=The 53 Percent Shrugged |last=Weigel |first=David |authorlink=David Weigel |date=September 20, 2012 |url= http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/politics/2012/09/creators_of_the_new_atlas_shrugged_ii_film_believe_it_speaks_to_mitt_romney_s_critique_of_47_percent_of_americans_.2.html |work=''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' |accessdate=June 24, 2013}}</ref> According to a report before the film was released, the film was to be on a 31-day shooting schedule, four days more than that of the first movie, and to undergo two months of post-production.<ref>{{cite web |title= On the Set of Atlas Shrugged Part II |url= http://reason.com/archives/2012/04/20/on-the-set-of-atlas-shrugged-part-ii |publisher=''[[Reason (magazine)|Reason]]'' |first= Brian |last= Doherty |authorlink= Brian Doherty (journalist) |date= April 20, 2012 |accessdate= April 21, 2012}}</ref>
==Reception==
===Pre-release=== ''Atlas Shrugged: Part II'' was not [[film screening|screen]]ed for critics before its release, with producer John Aglialoro questioning "the integrity of the critics".<ref name="FNC">{{cite web |url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2012/10/12/atlas-shrugged-part-ii-kept-from-mainstream-movie-critics-but-public-interest/ |title='Atlas Shrugged: Part II' kept from mainstream movie critics, but public interest remains high |last=McKay |first=Hollie |date=October 12, 2012 |work=[[FoxNews.com]] |accessdate=October 30, 2012}}</ref> The film was screened for the [[Conservatism in the United States|conservative]] think-tank [[The Heritage Foundation]] and the [[Libertarianism|libertarian]] [[Cato Institute]].<ref name="WSJ" />
===Box office===
''Atlas Shrugged: Part II'' opened on 1,012 screens and earned [[USD|$]]692,000 on its premiere<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.inquisitr.com/363039/atlas-shrugged-part-2-falters-at-the-north-american-box-office/ |title=‘Atlas Shrugged Part 2′ Falters At The North American Box Office |publisher=''The Inquisitr'' |date=October 14, 2012 |accessdate=January 28, 2013}}</ref> and $1.7 million its opening weekend, debuting at #11. Despite opening on more than three times the screens of ''Part I'', it did not significantly improve on ''Part I'''s opening weekend.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?yr=2012&wknd=40 |title=Weekend Box Office Results for October 5-7, 2012 |publisher=Box Office Mojo |date= |accessdate=January 28, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.politico.com/news/stories/1012/82399.html?hp=r7 |title=The box office shrugs at 'Atlas' |first=Patrick |last=Gavin |publisher=''[[Politico]]'' |date=October 15, 2012 |accessdate=January 28, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.altfg.com/blog/movie/atlas-shrugged-part-2-box-office-samantha-mathis/ |first=Zac |last=Gille |title=One of Worst Opening Weekends Ever at Domestic Box Office: ''Atlas Shrugged Part 2 |publisher=Alt Film Guie |date=February 6, 2013 |accessdate=June 24, 2013}}</ref>
The box office take totaled $3,286,255 through November 4, 2012, the last date for which the producers released numbers. When adjusted for inflation, the film had one of the two hundred least profitable wide openings of the past thirty years, followed by one of the two hundred largest week-over-week drops recorded for the same period. By the third week of release it was down to under 150 screens, taking in under $100,000 on its third weekend.<ref name="mojo" />
===Critical response===
Review aggregation website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gives the film a score of 4% based on reviews from 23 professional critics, with an average score of 3/10, and the site's consensus is: "Poorly written, clumsily filmed and edited, and hampered by amateurish acting, ''Atlas Shrugged: Part II'' does no favors to the ideology it so fervently champions".<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/atlas_shrugged_part_ii/ |title= Atlas Shrugged: Part II (2012) |publisher= [[Flixster]] | work = [[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate= November 16, 2013}}</ref> [[Metacritic]], which assigns a weighted average score out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, gives the film a score of 26 based on 11 reviews, which is interpreted as "Generally unfavorable" by Metacritic.<ref name="Metacritic">{{cite web |title=Atlas Shrugged Part 2 |url= http://www.metacritic.com/movie/atlas-shrugged-part-2 |publisher= [[CBS Interactive]]| work = [[Metacritic]] |accessdate=27 October 2012}}</ref>
Film critics were not impressed with the film based on several reviews: reviewer Danny Baldwin gave the film a "D" rating;<ref name="CS-20121012">{{cite web |last=Baldwin |first=Danny |title=Review: "Atlas Shrugged: Part II – The Strike" |url=http://www.criticspeak.com/review-atlas-shrugged-part-ii/ |date=October 12, 2012 |publisher=''CriticSpeak'' |accessdate=October 13, 2012}}</ref> while the ''[[New York Post]]'''s Kyle Smith gave the film a "1" rating (of 4), saying "...even if you overlooked the production values from a 1986 porno and special effects like something your nephew cooked up on his Mac, the movie's "Yay, money!" zingers are just a big bag of sad."<ref name="NYPost-20121012">{{cite web |last=Smith |first=Kyle |title=Saw the film & shrugged |url= http://www.nypost.com/p/entertainment/movies/saw_the_film_shrugged_fJIj4XwcW2XB6eW0TScgRI |date=October 12, 2012 |publisher=''[[New York Post]]'' |accessdate=October 13, 2012 }}</ref> Scott Tobias of [[The A.V. Club]] gave the film a grade of "F", citing lack of story progression and poor character designs,<ref>{{cite web |last= Tobias |first= Scott |title= Atlas Shrugged: Part II—The Strike |url= http://www.avclub.com/articles/atlas-shrugged-part-iithe-strike,86633/ |date=October 12, 2012 |publisher= [[The Onion]] | work = [[The A.V. Club]] |accessdate=October 13, 2012}}</ref> and named it the second-worst film of 2012, claiming, "The irony of Part II's mere existence is rich enough: The free market is a religion for Rand acolytes, and it emphatically rejected Part I."<ref name="AVClubWorst2012">{{cite web |url= http://www.avclub.com/articles/the-worst-films-of-2012,90103/ |title=The worst films of 2012 |publisher= The Onion | work = ''The A.V. Club'' |date= December 20, 2012 |accessdate=December 20, 2012}}</ref> Jim Lane of the [[Sacramento News & Review]] gave it a mixed review, calling it "a respectable effort hampered less by its limited budget than by the dogmatic contrivances of Rand's plot and the [[straw-man]] polemics of her wooden, declamatory dialogue."<ref name="JL">{{cite web |url= http://www.newsreview.com/sacramento/atlas-shrugged-part-2/content?oid=8118808 |title=Atlas Shrugged: Part 2 |last=Lane |first=Jim |date=October 18, 2012 |work=Sacramento News & Review |accessdate=November 7, 2012}}</ref>
Economics columnist John Tamny of [[Forbes.com]] gave the film a positive review and argued that it is "a must see because it in a very handsome way describes the world in which we live today whereby the achievers are being shackled by the moochers."'''''<ref name="JTF">{{cite web |url= https://www.forbes.com/sites/johntamny/2012/10/07/movie-review-why-atlas-shrugged-part-ii-is-a-must-see-film/ |title=Why Atlas Shrugged, Part II Is a Must See Film |last=Tamny |first=John |date=October 7, 2012 |work=[[Forbes]] |accessdate=November 7, 2012}}</ref>'''''
{{Anchor|Awards|Accolades}} The film was nominated for two [[33rd Golden Raspberry Awards|Golden Raspberry Awards]] including Worst Director for [[John Putch]] and Worst Screenplay.<ref>{{cite web |last=Bibbiani |first=William |title=The 33rd Annual Razzies (Dis)-Honor Twilight: Breaking Dawn: Part 2 |url= http://www.craveonline.com/film/articles/202737-the-33rd-annual-razzie-nominations-dishonors-twilight-saga-breaking-dawn-part-2 |publisher=CraveOnline |date=January 9, 2013 |accessdate=January 13, 2013}}</ref>
===Sequel=== {{Anchor|Home media|Sequels}} The sequel and the third part in the trilogy, ''[[Atlas Shrugged Part III: Who Is John Galt?]]'', was released on September 12, 2014.<ref name="av140619">{{cite news |first=Todd |last=VanDerWerff |work=[[The A.V. Club]] |title=Conclusion of Atlas Shrugged trilogy pulls out the big guns, casts Ron Paul |url=http://www.avclub.com/article/conclusion-atlas-shrugged-trilogy-pulls-out-big-gu-206019 |date=June 19, 2014 |accessdate=June 20, 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.AtlasShruggedPart2.com/}} * {{tcmdb title|id=886059|title=Atlas Shrugged Part 2}} * {{IMDb title|1985017|Atlas Shrugged Part 2}} {{rating|5.4|10}} * {{allrovi movie|568025|Atlas Shrugged Part 2}} {{rating|1.5|5}} * {{mojo title|atlasshruggedpart2|Atlas Shrugged Part 2}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|atlas_shrugged_part_2|Atlas Shrugged Part 2}} * {{metacritic film|atlas-shrugged-part-2|Atlas Shrugged Part 2}}
{{Ayn Rand|state=autocollapse}} {{John Putch}}

revision.comment: the work's name is "The New York Times"; italics on titles using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''Aviv "Vivi" Nevo''' ({{lang-he|אביב נבו}}; born 1965<ref name="iht">{{cite news|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/07/27/business/27viviNEW.php|accessdate=2008-07-28|title=Behind the scenes, a force in the media world|date=2008-07-28|first=Tim|last=Arango|work=International Herald Tribune}}</ref>) is an [[Israeli-American]] [[venture capitalist]]. He is a major shareholder in [[Time Warner]]<ref>Johnnie L. Roberts [http://www.newsweek.com/id/56499 Crunch Time] [[Newsweek]], August 22, 2005.</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Peter |last=Kwong |authorlink= |author= |coauthors= |title=Zhang Ziyi vs. Confucius |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2007/09/18/news/edkwong.php |format= |work= |publisher=International Herald Tribune |location= |id= |pages= |page= |date= 2007-07-18 |accessdate=2008-07-15 |language= |quote= }}</ref> and other companies, having built his fortune up from an initial $10 million inheritance.<ref name="iht" /> Nevo is said to be averse to [[publicity]]: He has consistently refused requests for interviews, and was referred to by friends as "the international man of mystery."<ref name="times2008"/>
==Early life== Nevo was born in [[Bucharest]] in [[Communist Romania]] and then moved to [[Tel Aviv]], [[Israel]] as an infant with his parents.<ref name="times2008"/> His father, a chemical engineer and his mother, an [[anesthesiologist]], eventually divorced. Nevo is an only child. He is Jewish.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.lovelovechina.com/celebrities/chinese-women-western-men-celebrity-couples/ | title=Chinese Women Western Men Celebrity Couples | publisher=Love Love China | accessdate=September 5, 2012}}</ref>
==Career== [[Stan Berk]], a former [[hedge fund]] manager who hired Nevo in the 1980s after they met at a Los Angeles gym, said Nevo worked for him from 1985 to 1988, and then "just disappeared." After a certain time period, they met again, and "Nevo had befriended billionaires and media titans.<ref name="thewrap">{{cite web | last=Waxman | first=Sharon | title=Vivi Nevo Revealed: 'Attention of a Hummingbird on Crack' | website=TheWrap | date=July 21, 2010 | url=https://www.thewrap.com/vivi-nevo-revealed-attention-hummingbird-19443/ | access-date=January 3, 2018}}</ref>
According to an anonymous business associate of Nevo, with an inheritance of around $10 million, Nevo set about investing and networking. ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that Nevo "opened trading accounts at Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, as well as Allen & Co., which eventually won him an invitation to Sun Valley... Through diligence and hard work, the right contacts and a lot of the right trades during the dot-com bubble of the late 1990s, he turned his inheritance into a sizable fortune ... Later on, Nevo began sprinkling money around in private companies, many of which were new media ventures."<ref name="times2008">{{cite web | last=Arango | first=Tim | title=Behind the scenes, a force in the media world | website=The New York Times | date=July 27, 2008 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/27/technology/27iht-27viviNEW.14814862.html | access-date=January 3, 2018}}</ref>
His [[venture capital]] firm, NV Investments, invests in technology companies worldwide, and is said to have been an early backer of [[The Weinstein Company]],<ref name=details>{{cite news|publisher=Details |url=http://men.style.com/details/features/full?id=content_4990&pageNum=8 |year=2008 |title=The power 50 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080608145209/http://men.style.com/details/features/full?id=content_4990&pageNum=8 |archivedate=2008-06-08 |df= }}</ref> and the largest individual shareholder in Time Warner.<ref name="iht" /> His estimated net worth is $500 million.<ref>{{cite web | title=The World's Most Entertaining Site | website=[[TheRichest (website)]] | date=1970-01-01 | url=https://www.therichest.com/celebnetworth/celebrity-business/investors/vivi-nevo-net-worth/ | access-date=2018-02-12}}</ref>
==Personal life== In July 2008 Nevo said that long-running rumors of an [[engagement]] to [[Chinese people|Chinese]] actress [[Zhang Ziyi]] were true.<ref>[https://www.smh.com.au/lifestyle/crouching-tiger-actor-zhang-ziyi-says-yes-to-boyfriends-drone-proposal-20150210-13ar1k.html 'Crouching Tiger' actor Zhang Ziyi says yes to boyfriend's drone proposal] Rachel Clun, ''[[Sydney Morning Herald]]'', 10 February 2015</ref> They separated in 2010.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2011/10/vivi-nevo-201110|title=Veni, Vidi, Vivi|last=Ward|first=Vicky|work=The Hive|access-date=2017-06-19|language=en}}</ref>
Nevo's circle of friends, and people he appeared with over the years, include: actress [[Blake Lively]], Morgan Stanley's John Marck, Citibank's [[Richard Parsons (businessman)|Dick Parsons]], billionaire Rob Perelman,<ref name="BI2011">{{cite web | last=Wachtel | first=Katya | title=Why Was Blake Lively Having Lunch Yesterday With Mysterious Financier And Investor Vivi Nevo? | website=Business Insider | date=2011-03-03 | url=http://www.businessinsider.com/blake-lively-had-lunch-yesterday-with-a-financier-vivi-nevo-2011-3 | access-date=2018-02-12}}</ref> media mogul [[Rupert Murdoch]], [[Lenny Kravitz]], [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], [[Leonardo DiCaprio]],<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-3784630/Leonardo-DiCaprio-takes-tennis-match-Open-supermodels-descend-games.html Daily Mail]</ref> and Apple's [[Tim Cook]].<ref>{{cite web | last=Oreskovic | first=Alexei | title=CAPTION CONTEST: What is this venture capitalist telling Apple CEO Tim Cook in this photo? | website=Business Insider | date=2017-07-14 | url=http://www.businessinsider.com/tim-cook-venture-capitalist-sun-valley-caption-contest-2017-7 | access-date=2018-02-12}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

The '''Azcárraga''' family is a wealthy [[Mexico|Mexican]] [[Mass media|media]] dynasty. The center of their business empire, [[Televisa]], is the main television network in Mexico and the largest producer and broadcaster of [[Spanish language]] media around the world.
Notable family members include: * [[Raúl Azcárraga Vidaurreta]]. Founder of [[XEW-AM|XEW]]. * [[Emilio Azcárraga Vidaurreta]], brother of the former. Founder of [[Televisa]]. * [[Emilio Azcárraga Milmo]], son of Emilio Azcárraga Vidaurreta. * [[Emilio Azcárraga Jean]], son of Azcárraga Milmo. Current president of Grupo Televisa.
==External links== * [http://www.museum.tv/archives/etv/A/htmlA/azcarragaem/azcarragaem.htm History of EAV and EAM] at the [[Museum of Broadcast Communications]].

{{advert|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox company | logo =| name = Caliper, A PerkinElmer Company | type = [[Public company|Public]] | foundation = 1995 | location = [[Hopkinton, Massachusetts]], United States num_employees = 543 [https://finance.yahoo.com/q/pr?s=calp] | industry = [[Biotechnology]]
[[Pharmaceuticals]]
[[Life Sciences]] | revenue = | homepage = [http://www.caliperls.com www.caliperls.com]| products = IVIS [[optical imaging]] systems
[[Liquid handling]] workstations
Plate management systems
[[evaporation]] & [[solid phase extraction]] products
[[In vivo]] imaging reagents
[[In vitro]] [[reagents]]
''In vivo'' contract research
In vitro contract research }} '''Caliper, A PerkinElmer Company''' is based in [[Hopkinton, Massachusetts]] with direct sales, service and application-support operations in countries around the globe. Founded in 1995, Caliper develops products and services to the life sciences research community, including [[pharmaceutical]] and [[biotechnology]] companies, and government and other not-for profit research institutions. Caliper’s integrated systems, consisting of instruments, software and [[reagents]], [[laboratory automation]] tools and [[drug discovery]] assay services enable researchers to better understand the basis for disease and more effectively discover safe and effective drugs. Caliper’s product portfolio includes, [[microfluidics]], lab automation & liquid handling, optical imaging technologies, and [[drug discovery]] & [[drug development]] outsourcing solutions. == Microfluidic platform == Caliper is a pioneer in [[microfluidic]] [[lab-on-a-chip]] technology which represents a significant advancement in laboratory experimentation, bringing the benefits of miniaturization, integration and automation to numerous research-based industries. Caliper’s proprietary microfluidic sipper chips are a high-throughput complement to the planar chips which Caliper manufactures for the Agilent Bioanalyzer 2100. The microfluidic technology forms the basis of Caliper’s LabChip EZ reader systems used for drug screening and profiling and the LabChip GX series for molecular biology [[DNA]], [[RNA]] and [[protein analysis]]. == Optical imaging == Through its acquisition of Xenogen Corporation in 2006, Caliper is now a developer of [[in vivo]] biophotonic imaging technology, which allows for real-time, non-invasive exploration of [[genes]], proteins, pathogens, and tumor cells in living animals.{{cite journal | title=Advancing bioluminescence imaging technology for the evaluation of anticancer agents in the MDA-MB-435-HAL-Luc mammary fat pad and subrenal capsule tumor models.| date=2009-01-01 | publisher=| pmid=19118051| doi=10.1158/1078-0432.CCR-08-0897| volume=15| issue=1| journal=Clin. Cancer Res.| pages=238–46}} Caliper offers a complement of patented biophotonic and fluorescent imaging technologies, as well as genetically modified animal programs. Caliper’s imaging product lines include a suite of IVIS imaging systems - many measuring both bioluminescence and fluorescence, ''in vivo'' imaging reagents, specialized light producing animal models, and genetic modification programs for pharmaceutical and biotechnology research and development. In a recent Japanese study, the IVIS imaging system was used to evaluate the binding affinity and RNA interference ([[RNAi]]) of LMWC/[[siRNA]] complexes.{{cite journal | title=Evaluation of the binding affinity and RNA interference of low-molecular-weight chitosan/siRNA complexes using an imaging system | date=2008-10-30 | publisher=| pmid=19337002 | volume=129 | issue=4 | journal=Yakugaku Zasshi | pages=475–84 | doi=10.1248/yakushi.129.475}} == Lab automation and liquid handling == Caliper has held a long standing position in laboratory automation starting with the introduction of the world’s first lab robotic system, the Zymark Zymate. To date, Caliper has a number of lab automation and liquid handling systems for the life sciences industry. In January 2009, the Zephyr Genomics Workstation was introduced which promises to deliver a benchtop solution for automating routine but critical processes for [[molecular biology]] such as [[nucleic acid purification]], reaction setup and normalization. In addition to automating molecular biology, Caliper has many other [[robotic]] systems including the Zephyr SPE and RapidTrace SPE workstations to automate [[solid phase extraction]] and several liquid handling and plate management systems including the Sciclone ALH 3000 liquid handler and Twister II systems to automate drug discovery and development. Caliper also custom designs integrated vendor-neutral instruments and software such as the Twister II - LightCycler (Roche) integrated system which fully automates real-time [[PCR]]. == Discovery and development outsourcing solutions == Caliper’s Discovery Alliances & Services division (CDAS) was created from the acquisitions of NovaScreen, a provider of [[in vitro]] & [[in vivo]] discovery services. CDAS develops, utilizes, and provides a comprehensive array of services to improve the productivity, accelerate the pace, and reduce the cost of the [[drug discovery]] process. The ''in vitro'' service arm of CDAS includes a comprehensive array of ''in vitro'' drug discovery and development solutions including more than 1000 screening [[assays]] that help define the mode of action, side effect profiles, selectivity, and other relevant activities of drug candidates. ''In vivo'' capabilities include: non-invasive ''in vivo'' [[optical imaging]], OncoMouse studies, and ''in vivo'' compound evaluations for safety assessment and [[drug repositioning]]. == History == Caliper Life Sciences was founded in 1995 by [[Larry Bock]] and Drs. Michael Knapp, Michael Ramsey and Andreas Manz. as Caliper Technologies with a strong focus on microfluidics technology. In 2003, Caliper acquired Zymark a leader in laboratory automation and robotics and Caliper Life Sciences was born. In October 2005, Caliper acquired NovaScreen Biosciences Corporation a privately held CRO offering pre-clinical drug discovery and development services. NovaScreen’s services included ''in vitro'' compound profiling for safety assessment, drug discovery screening services for targets such as GPCRs, Kinases, Ion Channels, Transporters, Nuclear Receptors and customized assay development services. In August 2006, Caliper acquired Xenogen Corporation, a developer of ''in vivo'' optical imaging systems (IVIS systems) and its division, Xenogen Biosciences a CRO offering ''in vivo'' transgenic animal production, phenotyping, gene targeting and ''in vivo'' optical imaging services. At the end of October 2008, SOTAX—a tester and software developer of medical devices—acquired Caliper's Pharmaceutical Development & Quality Analysis (PDQ) Division for $15.8 Million.{{cite news | title=Caliper sells biz unit for $15.8M to SOTAX | date=2008-10-30 | publisher=Mass High Tech | url=http://www.masshightech.com/stories/2008/10/27/daily33-Caliper-sells-biz-unit-for-158M-to-SOTAX.html}}{{cite news | title=Caliper Grabs $15.8M In Product Line Sale | date=2008-10-30 | publisher=Worcester Business Journal | url=http://www.wbjournal.com/news41938.html}} Shortly thereafter on November 10, 2008, Caliper's AutoTrace(r) line of product was acquired by [[Dionex]].{{cite news | title=Dionex Enters Into Agreement With Caliper Life Sciences to Acquire Product Line for Water Sample Preparation | date=2008-11-10 | publisher=MarketWatch | url=http://www.marketwatch.com/news/story/Dionex-Enters-Into-Agreement-With/story.aspx?guid=28223301-9045-48B7-A4B0-FEF2C02E2C73}} In December 2009, [[Taconic Biosciences]] acquired XenoGen Biosciences ''in vivo'' pre-clinical CRO subsidiary of Caliper Life Sciences.{{cite news | title=Taconic Acquires Xenogen Biosciences Subsidiary of Caliper Life Sciences| date=2009-12-14 | publisher=Taconic | url=http://www.taconic.com/resources/newsroom/2009/xenogen-biosciences}} A year later in December 2010, Caliper purchased Cambridge Research & Instrumentation Inc. for about $20 million in a cash and stock deal.{{cite news | title=Caliper buying Cambridge Research for $20 million | date=2010-12-09 | publisher=Bloomberg | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-12-09/caliper-buying-cambridge-research-for-20-million.html}} In September 2011, PerkinElmer agreed to buy Caliper Life Sciences for $600 million.{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/09/08/perkinelmer-caliper-idUSN1E7861IY20110908 | title = PerkinElmer to buy Caliper for $600 mln | author = Reuters | accessdate = 2011-09-08 | date=2011-09-08}} On November 7, 2011, PerkinElmer completed the acquisition of Caliper Life Sciences for a total net purchase price of approximately $600 million in cash.{{cite web | url = http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20111107006528/en/PerkinElmer-Completes-Acquisition-Caliper-Life-Sciences | title = PerkinElmer Completes Acquisition of Caliper Life Sciences | author = Business Wire | accessdate = 2011-11-07}} == Intellectual property == Caliper's portfolio of microfluidics-related patents has been ranked as high as #2 in technological strength in the Biotech/Pharma sector of the MIT Technology Review Patent Scorecard. Caliper actively out-licenses this portfolio as part of its Caliper Driven program to broaden and accelerate the availability of new technologies and products for life science and diagnostics applications. Licensing Caliper's microfluidic intellectual property benefits existing and potential partners by enhancing the strength of their product and service offerings through the incorporation of Caliper’s technology. Caliper also provides commercial and academic customers with proprietary methods via its Optical Imaging Patent Suite. The notification of allowance of Caliper’s patent claims for conjugate fluorescence imaging methods from the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office has added yet another valuable component to Caliper's widespread intellectual property estate. ==Acquisition history== * 1995 - Caliper Technologies Corporation is formed * 1999 - Caliper goes public in $75 Million offering * 2003 - Acquires Zymark * 2004 - Company changes name to Caliper Life Sciences * 2005 - Acquires NovaScreen Biosciences Corporation * 2006 - Acquires Xenogen * 2010 - Acquires Cambridge Research & Instrumentation Inc. * 2011 - Acquired by [[PerkinElmer]] ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.caliperls.com/}} * [http://finance.google.com/finance?q=calp&btnG=Search Caliper, A PerkinElmer Company] Company Profile at Google Finance. [[Category:Biotechnology companies of the United States]] [[Category:Life sciences industry]] [[Category:Medical technology companies of the United States]] [[Category:Biotechnology companies established in 1995]] [[Category:1995 establishments in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 1995]]

{{Infobox business park | name = | image = Cambridge_Science_Park_main_entrance.jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = The main entrance to Cambridge Science Park | map_type = | relief = | map_size = | map_dot_label = | map_alt = | map_caption = | location = [[Milton, Cambridge]] | address = Milton Road | coordinates = {{coord|52|14|2|N|0|8|40|E}} | opening_date = Autumn 1973<ref name="ci">{{cite web|url=http://www.cambridgeindependent.co.uk/business/business-news/we-want-to-inject-more-soul-into-the-science-park-says-inaugural-director-1-5173003|title=‘We want to inject more soul into the Science Park’, says inaugural director|date=3 September 2017|access-date=27 January 2018}}</ref> | closing_date = | developer = [[Bidwells]]<ref name="ci"/> | construction_cost = | manager = Jeanette Walker<ref name="ci"/> | owner = [[Trinity College, Cambridge]], [[Trinity Hall, Cambridge]]<ref name="ci"/> | architect = | number_of_tenants = 90<ref name="ci"/> | number_of_workers = | size = 173 acres<ref name="ci"/> | parking = | website = [http://www.cambridgesciencepark.co.uk/ www.cambridgesciencepark.co.uk] | footnotes = }}
The '''Cambridge Science Park''', founded by [[Trinity College, Cambridge|Trinity College]] in 1970,<ref>[[#BPGCSE]]</ref> is the oldest [[science park]] in the United Kingdom. It is a concentration of science and technology related businesses, and has strong links with the nearby [[University of Cambridge]].
The science park is situated about 3 km to the north of [[Cambridge]] city centre, by junction 33 of the [[A14 road (Great Britain)|A14]], in the parish of [[Milton, Cambridgeshire|Milton]], contiguous with Cambridge itself. The park is served by [[Cambridge North railway station]] and by the [[Cambridgeshire Guided Busway]]. It is directly adjacent to [[St John's Innovation Centre]] and [[Cambridge Business Park]].
==History==
The land was originally given to [[Trinity College, Cambridge|Trinity College]] when the latter was founded by [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]] in 1546. The land was used for farming until the [[Second World War]], when it was requisitioned by the [[US Army]] and used to prepare vehicles and tanks for [[D-Day]]. After the war, the land was left derelict until 1970, when, at the suggestion of [[Tony Cornell]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/Cambridge/Ghostbuster-who-had-the-spirit-to-persevere.htm|title=Ghostbuster who had the spirit to persevere|publisher=Cambridge Evening News|date=16 April 2010|accessdate=24 April 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322082346/http://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/Cambridge/Ghostbuster-who-had-the-spirit-to-persevere.htm|archivedate=22 March 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and under the supervision of [[John Bradfield (scientist)|Sir John Bradfield]], the college worked with Sir Francis Pemberton of [[Bidwells]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/Home/Great-man-Sir-Francis-dies-at-95-04112011.htm|title='Great man' Sir Francis dies at 95|publisher=Cambridge Evening News|date=6 November 2011|accessdate=21 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201174558/http://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/Home/Great-man-Sir-Francis-dies-at-95-04112011.htm|archivedate=1 February 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> to develop it into a new centre for scientific enterprise and innovation.
In 2017, following decades of rapid expansion in Cambridge, the park appointed its first director and announced a large investment intended to improve facilities and reduce traffic congestion.<ref name="ci"/>
==Notable companies==
===Bio-medical===
*[[Abcam]] *[[Amgen]] *[[Astex]] *[[AstraZeneca]] *[[Bayer]] *[[British American Tobacco]] *[[Dr. Reddy's Laboratories]] *[[Royal Society of Chemistry]] *[[Sigma-Aldrich]] *[[Palmer's Garden Centre]]
===Computer/telecoms===
*[[Arthur D. Little]] *[[Broadcom]] *[[Citrix Systems]] *[[Cryptomathic]] *[[Dassault Systèmes]] *[[DisplayLink]] *[[FlexEnable]] *[[Frontier Developments]] *[[Huawei]] *[[Jagex]] *[[Linguamatics]] *[[Ricardo plc]] *[[Toshiba]] *[[Vix Technology]]
===Industrial technology===
*[[Aveva]] *[[Beko]] *[[Heraeus]] *[[Johnson Matthey]] *[[Philips]] *[[Roku, Inc.]] *[[Xaar plc]]
===Other===
*[[Cambridge Assessment]] *[http://Www.CambridgeConsultants.com Cambridge Consultants] *[[Grant Thornton LLP]] *[[Worldpay]]
==Cambridge Fun Run==
The Cambridge Fun Run is a charity race for [[Children in Need]] organised and mainly entered by employees of businesses based in and around the Science Park. It has been held each November since 1989. Contestants compete in teams of four, some in fancy dress, running either one lap (as a group) or four laps (as a relay) of the {{convert|1.1|mi|km|abbr=on|disp=flip}} Science Park ring road. The race begins and ends, and medals and trophies are awarded (for fastest runners and best costumes) in front of the [http://www.Cambridge.Consultants.com Cambridge Consultants] building.<ref>[http://www.camfunrun.org/about/ Cambridge Fun Run in aid of Children in Need] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111121212919/http://www.camfunrun.org/about/ |date=21 November 2011 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.cambridgefirst.co.uk/news/gallery_600_workers_pass_the_baton_for_children_in_need_1_1130867 GALLERY: 600 workers pass the baton for Children in Need] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111120170730/http://www.cambridgefirst.co.uk/news/gallery_600_workers_pass_the_baton_for_children_in_need_1_1130867 |date=20 November 2011 }}</ref> {{-}} ==Gallery==
<gallery widths="160"> File:Cambridge Science Park rear entrance.jpg|The rear entrance File:Cambridge Science Park Cambridge Consultants.jpg|The [http://www.Cambridge.Consultants.com Cambridge Consultants] building File:Cambridge Science Park Broadcom.jpg|The [[Broadcom]] building File:Cambridge Science Park Innovation Centre.jpg|The Innovation Centre File:Cambridge Science Park Trinity Centre.jpg|The Trinity Centre entrance File:Cambridge Science Park gym.jpg|The health and fitness club File:Cambridge Science Park restaurant pond.jpg|The 2wenty4 restaurant overlooking the south pond File:Cambridge Science Park east pond.jpg|The northeast pond File:Cambridge Science Park west pond.jpg|The northwest pond </gallery>
==See also== * [[Cambridge Science Park railway station]] * [[Cambridge Business Park]] * [[John Bradfield (scientist)|John Bradfield]] * [[Oxford Science Park]] * [[List of science parks in the United Kingdom]] * [[Silicon Fen]] * [[Colworth Science Park]]

{{Use British English|date=January 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Spanish name|'''Marranzini'''|'''Pérez'''}} {{Infobox person | name = Celso Marranzini | honorific-suffix = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1952|01|11}} | baptism_date = | birth_place = [[Santo Domingo]], [[Dominican Republic]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | nationality = [[People of the Dominican Republic|Dominican]] | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = | years_active = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = his role in CONEP and CDEEE | notable_works = | style = | home_town = | salary = RD$3.6 million in 2008 | height = | weight = | boards = [[Corporación Dominicana de Empresas Elécticas Estatales]] | religion = | denomination = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = Constantino Marranzini (father),
María Altagracia Pérez-Pintado (mother) | relatives = [[Frank Rainieri|Frank Rainieri Marranzini]] (second-cousin) | callsign = | awards = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Celso José Marranzini Pérez''' (born 11 January 1952, [[Santo Domingo]]) is an economist and businessman from the Dominican Republic. Vice President of ''Corporación Dominicana de Empresas Eléctricas Estatales'' (CDEEE, "Dominican Corporation of State Electrical Companies");{{cite web|title=Declaración Jurada de Bienes de Funcionario Público|url=http://transparencia.cdeee.gob.do/Documentos/Declaraciones/1%20-%20Lic.%20Celso%20Marranzini%20P..pdf|website=Corporación Dominicana de Empresas Eléctricas Estatales|accessdate=25 January 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150125052838/http://transparencia.cdeee.gob.do/Documentos/Declaraciones/1%20-%20Lic.%20Celso%20Marranzini%20P..pdf|archivedate=25 January 2015|language=Spanish|date=2009}} former chairman of ''Consejo Nacional de la Empresa Privada'' (CONEP, "National Council of the Private Enterprise").{{cite news|title=Celso Marranzini auspicia defensoría para víctimas de TelexFree en el país|url=http://www.diariolibre.com/economia/2014/07/30/i723021_celso-marranzini-auspicia-defensora-para-vctimas-telexfree-pas.html|accessdate=25 January 2015|publisher=Diario Libre|date=30 July 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150125053341/http://www.diariolibre.com/economia/2014/07/30/i723021_celso-marranzini-auspicia-defensora-para-vctimas-telexfree-pas.html|archivedate=25 January 2015|location=Santo Domingo|language=Spanish}} He was born to Constantino Marranzini Risk (the son of Liberato Marranzini, an Italian immigrant from [[Santa Lucia di Serino]], and Amelia Risk, of Lebanese descent) and María Altagracia Pérez Pintado (the daughter of Celso Pérez, a Spanish industrialist from [[Asturias]], and Carmen Pintado, who was born in Puerto Rico to Spanish parents).{{cite news|last1=Marranzini|first1=Celso|title=Puerto Rico en problemas|url=http://www.elcaribe.com.do/2015/05/20/puerto-rico-problemas|accessdate=20 May 2015|publisher=El Caribe|date=20 May 2015|language=Spanish}}{{cite news|last1=Calderón|first1=Arismendy|title=Al servicio de los más necesitados|url= http://hoy.com.do/al-servicio-de-los-mas-necesitados/ |accessdate=20 May 2015|publisher=Hoy|date=17 August 2008|language=Spanish}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Marranzini, Celso}} [[Category:People from Santo Domingo]] [[Category:Dominican Republic people of Italian descent]] [[Category:Dominican Republic people of Lebanese descent]] [[Category:Dominican Republic people of Spanish descent]] [[Category:Dominican Republic people of Asturian descent]] revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=November 2010}} '''Computer aided call handling''' is a methodology for managing calls to service providers, such as emergency services, through the use of computer based algorithms in order to make consistent and objective decisions on action to be taken. The computer software can provide scripting, prompts or interactive questioning to assist the call handler in gathering information.
The algorithms in the software will depend on the requirements of the service provider, the resources they have available, and the information that may be useful to resources dispatched or assigned to the call. The output is likely to be a prioritised list of tasks for action, where the action could be passing to another remote service (such as a telephony centre), dispatching a physical resource (such as an [[ambulance]], [[police car]] or recovery truck) or closing the call without action. The advantage in using a computer based system is objectivity in decisions made, meaning a consistent service delivery.
Call handling software can be linked to [[computer aided dispatch]] in order that this process is fully integrated, and information from the call handling software is passed directly to dispatch software where appropriate.<ref>[http://www.freepatentsonline.com/7646858.html Protocol builder for a call handling system]</ref> This could also mean dispatching services which are not part of the organisation using the call handling software, such as an ambulance control centre automatically dispatching police to a violent incident, without the requirement to involve a further operator.<ref>[http://www.powerphone.com/dev/news/pdf/PowerPhone_ENP_CACH_Article.pdf Computer-Aided Call Handling: Improving Technology at the Front End of Dispatch] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715111233/http://www.powerphone.com/dev/news/pdf/PowerPhone_ENP_CACH_Article.pdf |date=2011-07-15 }}</ref>
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Computer Aided Call Handling}} [[Category:Logistics]] [[Category:Public safety communications]]

{{Infobox person | image = Czesław Warsewicz.jpg | image_size = | name = Czesław Warsewicz | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1969 | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = Polish | religion = | ethnicity = | residence = | education = | alma mater = [[Warsaw School of Economics]] | known for = | salary = | networth = | spouse = | parents = | children = | website = }} '''Czesław Warsewicz''' (born 1969) – Polish businessman and entrepreneur.
==Education== Warsewicz graduated in economics from [[Warsaw School of Economics]] in 1994 and from [[IESE Business School]] (Advanced Management Program, 2007).
==Business career== He took part in privatisation of a few [[Poland|Polish]] companies, and before starting his job with [[PKP Intercity]] he was the CFO in [[Rolimpex-Nasiona Sp. z o.o.]] (1998 – 2006)<ref>[http://www.augeo.pl/?idl=2&idp=25 Czesław Warsewicz short profile]</ref>. In the years 2006 - 2009, the President of the PKP Intercity SA Management Board. Currently, the President of the Management Board of a strategic consulting company under the name "Blue Ocean" Business Consulting sp. O.o., specializing in the development of transport plans for local government units. Member of the [[Law and Justice]] Program Council responsible for preparing the program in the field of transport, in particular rail.
Since March 2018 CEO [[PKP Cargo|PKP Cargo S.A.]]<ref>[https://www.pb.pl/czeslaw-warsewicz-nowym-prezesem-pkp-cargo-908961 ''Czesław Warsewicz nowym prezesem PKP Cargo'' - pb.pl]</ref>
==Awards and commendations== * 2009 Wektor-Award of [[Employers of Poland|Konfederacji Pracodawców Polskich]]<ref>[http://kolej.com.pl/kto_jest_kim_w_transporcie/ludzie_transportu/osoba,Warsewicz_Czeslaw,rid,140.html ''Czesław Warsewicz - Bio'' - kolej.com.pl]</ref>.
== References == <references/>

revision.text:
'''Data Discovery and Query Builder''' (DDQB) is a data abstraction technology, developed by [[IBM]], that allows users to retrieve information from a data warehouse, in terms of the user's specific area of expertise instead of SQL.
DDQB serves the user through a web based graphical user interface and configurable data abstraction model (DAM), which contains both an understanding of the user knowledge domain and the database below it.
DDQB uses a set of [[Eclipse (software)|Eclipse]]-based customization tooling and can be deployed as a set of [[Web Services]].
==See also== * [[Business Intelligence]] * [[Ad hoc|Ad hoc query]] * [[Full text search]] * [[Unstructured information]] * [[Data access]] * [[Information retrieval]] * [[Information science]] * [[Web Services]]
==External links== * [http://www.eweek.com/c/a/Health-Care-IT/Mayo-Clinic-Taps-IBM-Tools-to-Mine-Patient-Data Data Virtualization through IBM and Mayo Clinic Collaboration]
==Related Papers== * [http://www.gridforum.nl/files/IBM-Grids-internship-report-AdL.pdf W.A. de Landgraaf, Data grids in theory and practice, 2008]
[[Category:Business intelligence]] [[Category:Data analysis software]]

revision.text:
'''Direct therapeutic exposure''' ('''DTE''') is a [[behavior therapy]] technique pioneered by Patrick A. Boudewyns, where [[stressor]]s are vividly and safely confronted to help combat [[veteran]]s, and patients suffering from [[posttraumatic stress disorder]] (PTSD), [[panic disorder]], or [[phobia]]s. [[Exposure therapy]] has supporting evidence with both simple and complex traumas.<ref>Baschnagel, J.S., Coffey, S.F., and Rash, C.J. (2006). The Treatment of Co-Occurring PTSD and Substance Use Disorders Using Trauma-Focused Exposure Therapy. IJBCT 2(4), 498-508. [http://www.baojournal.com BAO]</ref> A similar therapy is [[Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing]] (EMDR). First known publication in book form is ''Flooding and Implosive Therapy: Direct Therapeutic Exposure in Clinical Practice'' by Patrick A. Boudewyns, Robert H. Shipley. 1983. {{ISBN|0-306-41155-5}}.
It is not uncommon to combine DTE treatment with other therapies.
==Use==
Direct exposure has been used with a variety of populations including agoraphobia<ref>Katherine Porter, Carole Porcari, Ellen I. Koc, Courtney Fons and C. Richard Spates (2006): In vivo Exposure Treatment For Agoraphobia. The Behavior Analyst Today, 7(3) 434 -445. [http://www.baojournal.com]</ref> and chronic PTSD<ref>Afsoon Eftekhari, Lisa R. Stines and Lori A. Zoellner (2005): Do You Need To Talk About It? Prolonged Exposure for the Treatment of Chronic PTSD. ''The Behavior Analyst Today, 7(1),'' 70- 84 [http://www.abojournal.com]</ref> It involves as the name applies placing the client either real or imaginally in the feared situation.
==See also== Other techniques for treating PTSD: * [[Cognitive behavior therapy]] * [[Emotionally focused therapy]] * [[Expressive therapy]] * [[Family therapy]] * [[Outward Bound]] * [[Prolonged exposure therapy]] * [[Psychodynamic psychotherapy]]
==References== {{reflist}}
Boudewyns, P.A. & Hyer, L. (1990). "Physiological Response to Combat Memories and Preliminary Treatment Outcome in Vietnam Veteran PTSD patients treated with Direct Therapeutic Exposure." ''Behavior Therapy'', 21, 63-87.
== External links == * [http://www.fsu.edu/~trauma/v6i4/v6i4a2.htm A Review of Alternative Approaches to the Treatment of Post Traumatic Sequelae]
{{Cognitive behavioral therapy}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Direct Therapeutic Exposure}} [[Category:Anxiety disorder treatment]] [[Category:Counseling]] [[Category:Traumatology]]
{{Treatment-stub}}

revision.comment: Link Philip Green to Philip Green Wiki page
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=November 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} '''Dominic Joseph Andrew Chappell''' (born 28 November 1966) is a British businessman and former [[Auto racing|racing driver]],<ref name=sref/> who has been declared bankrupt on two occasions.<ref name=BBC36241660/> In 2015, his company, Retail Acquisitions Ltd, purchased the now collapsed retail chain [[British Home Stores]] from [[Philip Green]] for just £1 GBP together with a £10,000,000 equity injection into BHS Group Ltd. 13 months later the company was placed into administration resulting in the closure of 164 stores and the loss of 11,000 jobs.<ref>{{cite news|title=BHS to close with loss of 11,000 jobs and 164 shops after rescue bids fail to find a buyer|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=2 June 2016|accessdate=2 June 2016|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2016/06/02/fate-of-bhss-11000-workers-to-be-sealed-as-decision-looms-for-tr/}}</ref>
==Biography== Chappell was born in [[Sunbury on Thames]], Surrey in 1966. He was educated at [[Millfield School]] in Somerset.<ref name="ft">{{cite news|title=Revealed: the trail of disasters behind mystery buyer of BHS|first=Oliver|last=Shah|date=29 March 2015|work=[[The Sunday Times]]|location=London|url=http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/business/Finance/article1537298.ece|accessdate=25 April 2016}}</ref>
Chappell competed from 1986 to 1999 including British [[Formula Ford 2000]], and [[British Formula Three|British F3]] in [[1990 British Formula Three season|1990]], finishing runner up in the Class B Championship and British Formula 3000, Chappell competed in the [[24 Hours of Le Mans]] race in the GT1 class in [[1994 24 Hours of Le Mans|1994]] (not classified), [[1995 24 Hours of Le Mans|1995]] (did not finish) and [[1996 24 Hours of Le Mans|1996]] (did not finish),<ref name=sref>{{cite web|title=Dominic Chappell|url=http://www.driverdb.com/drivers/dominic-chappell/career/|work=Driver Database|accessdate=8 July 2012}}</ref> and entered in the GT2 class in [[1997 24 Hours of Le Mans|1997]] but failed to qualify.<ref name=LeMans1997>{{cite web|title=1997 24 Hours of Le Mans|url=http://www.experiencelemans.com/contents/en-us/d140_1997_Le_Mans_24_Hours_Competitors_and_Results.html|work=Results and Competitors|accessdate=8 June 2016}}</ref>
Chappell launched the Interactive Sportscar Championship in the UK in 2001. The series folded after one race, leaving almost everybody unpaid, despite promises of payment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://oppositelock.kinja.com/the-amusing-cautionary-tale-of-the-isc-1726823985|title=The Amusing Cautionary Tale of the ISC|last=hsv|website=Oppositelock|access-date=12 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/simonneville/the-man-who-wants-to-buy-back-bhs-tried-and-failed-to-launch|title=The Man Who Wants To Buy Back BHS Tried And Failed To Launch A Racing Franchise|website=BuzzFeed|access-date=12 June 2016}}</ref>
In August 2016, Chappell was disqualified from holding a driving licence for six months and fined after pleading guilty to driving at over 63{{nbsp}}mph in a 40{{nbsp}}mph zone in [[Andover, Hampshire]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Ex-BHS boss Dominic Chappell loses licence over speeding|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=23 August 2016|accessdate=23 August 2016|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-36939820}}</ref>
==Business career== [[File:Island Harbour Marina.jpg|thumb|[[Island Harbour Marina]]]] [[File:British Home Stores closing down sale Wood Green, London 3 August 2016 06.jpg|thumb|The closing down sale for a British Home Stores branch in London.]] Chappell has been a director of various failed companies, and has been made bankrupt twice<ref name=BBC36241660>{{cite news|title=Third bankruptcy of BHS buyer revealed|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-36241660|accessdate=8 May 2016|publisher=BBC|date=8 May 2016}}</ref> and entered into an [[individual voluntary arrangement]] once.
He was involved in the [[Island Harbour Marina]] development on the [[Isle of Wight]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.iwcp.co.uk/news/news/assurance-over-bhs-future-after-high-street-chain-sold-to-former-island-harbour-owner-78505.aspx |title=Isle of Wight: Assurance over BHS future after high street chain sold to former Island Harbour owner |work=[[Isle of Wight County Press]]|location=Newport|date=13 March 2015|accessdate=30 March 2015}}</ref>
It was reported in 2015 that Chappell, with the backing of investors, became the 90% owner of [[Retail Acquisitions]], the firm that acquired [[British Home Stores]] (BHS) from [[Sir Philip Green]] for £1.<ref>{{cite news|last=Neilan |first=Catherine |url=http://www.cityam.com/211443/here-everything-we-know-about-new-owners-bhs-retail-acquisitions-and-what-it-planning |title=Here is everything we know about BHS' new owner Retail Acquisitions, and what it is planning for the department store|work=[[City A.M.]]|location=London |date=12 March 2015 |accessdate=30 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Sarah |last=Butler |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/mar/13/bhs-sale-store-that-failed-to-battle-it-out-on-high-street |title=BHS sale: the store that failed to battle it out on the high street |work=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|accessdate=30 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.itv.com/news/update/2015-03-12/struggling-bhs-sold-to-consortium-for-1/ |title=Struggling BHS sold to consortium for £1 |work=[[ITV News]]|location=London |date=12 March 2015|accessdate=30 March 2015}}</ref>
It subsequently transpired that instead of injecting new capital into the cash-strapped company as agreed with Arcadia, Chappell extracted £1,789,250 within three months of acquiring control of BHS.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.parliament.uk/documents/commons-committees/business-innovation-and-skills/Correspondence/2015-20-Parliament/Olswang-to-Pensions-Regulator-1-June-2015.pdf|title=Work and Pensions Committee BHS inquiry }}</ref>
During the 13-month period he controlled BHS, Chappell by his own admission, extracted a total of £2,627,643 from BHS.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.parliament.uk/documents/commons-committees/work-and-pensions/Correspondence/Dominic-Chappell-to-BIS-and-Work-and-Pensions-Committees-10-June-2016.pdf |title=Work and Pensions Committee BHS inquiry }}</ref>
On 26 April 2016, it was reported that when it became likely that BHS would be going into receivership Chappell had moved £1.5 million from the firm to a company owned by a friend who was also a fellow board member of Retail Acquisitions. The sum had been later refunded at the request of BHS' chief executive Darren Topp (less £50,000 bank transaction fees).<ref name="BBC News 26 April 2016">{{cite news |last= Jack |first= Simon |title= BHS owner tried to move cash out of firm |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-36146161| date= 26 April 2016| publisher= [[BBC News]] | accessdate=27 April 2016 }}</ref>
Just days after putting BHS into liquidation, and with its £571m pension deficit absorbed by the UK government's [[Pension Protection Fund]], Chappell was said to be considering re-purchasing some parts of the firm.<ref name="City A.M. 27 April 2016">{{cite news |last= Neilan |first= Catherine |title= Blame game kicks off following BHS failure |url= http://www.cityam.com/239888/blame-game-kicks-off-following-bhs-failure-| date= 27 April 2016|newspaper= [[City A.M.]] |location=London| accessdate=27 April 2016 }}</ref> Reporting on this development, the BBC's Business editor [[Simon Jack]] noted: "Sources at BHS treated the announcement with bewilderment. Other very senior retail sources used more colourful language. His credibility has taken a very serious knock. The details that have emerged about Dominic Chappell and his fellow directors' extraction of millions in professional fees has attracted widespread criticism".<ref name="BBC News 27 April 2016">{{cite web |last= Jack |first= Simon |title= Is Dominic Chappell's BHS bid serious?|url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-36153514| date= 27 April 2016| publisher= [[BBC News]] | accessdate= 27 April 2016 }}</ref>
On 2 September 2016, another Chappell owned company, Swiss Rock plc was put into liquidation. The Statement of Affairs included unpaid VAT debts of £365,000 and outstanding Corporation Tax of £197,306.<ref name="The Guardian 05 September 2016">{{cite news |last= Ruddick |first= Graham |title= HMRC begins legal battle with Dominic Chappell over tax |url= https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/23/ex-bhs-boss-dominic-chappell-ordered-to-pay-87000-in-pensions-case | date= 5 September 2016| work= [[The Guardian]] | accessdate= 5 September 2016 }}</ref>
Retail Acquisitions Limited, the company used by Chappell to take over BHS in 2015 was wound up by the High Court of Justice on 3 May 2017 on the petition of BHS owed £6.1M in respect of an unpaid loan <ref name="The Gazette 23 May 2017">{{cite web | title= Official Public Record | url= https://www.thegazette.co.uk/notice/2787117 | date= 23 May 2017 | work= [[The London Gazette]] }}</ref>. Chappell had previously disclosed that Retail Acquisitions Limited had paid £1.5M to settle a mortgage debt secured on his parents’ home.<ref name="The Guardian 29 April 2016">{{cite news |last= Ruddick |first= Graham |title= BHS collapse: more details emerge on Retail Acquisitions' loans |url= https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/apr/29/bhs-collapse-dominic-chappell-could-be-forced-to-repay-millions| date= 29 April 2016| work= [[The Guardian]] }}</ref>
Chappell was found guilty of three charges of neglecting or refusing to provide information and documents to The Pensions Regulator at Brighton Magistrates’ Court on 11 January 2018 and ordered to pay a fine of £50,000 and £37,000 court costs. Chappell said he could not pay because he had “no funds”, and claimed he had extensive outgoings, of almost £9,000 per month made up of: £3,800 a month rent on a Dorset mansion; £2,666 a month leasing a 2017-plate Range Rover; and £2,500 a month school fees for his two children, aged eight and 12, on which he was in arrears. <ref name="The Guardian 23 February 2018">{{cite news |title= Ex-BHS boss Dominic Chappell ordered to pay £87,000 in pensions case |url= https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/sep/05/hmrc-dominic-chappell-tax-high-court-petition-bhs-swiss-rock| date= 23 February 2018| work= [[The Guardian]] }}</ref>
Chappell is currently appealing the sentence which is due to be heard in September 2018
On 27 March 2018 the UK Insolvency Service announced that intends to ban Chappell, and three other former BHS directors, from serving as company directors for up to 15 years, following its investigation into the collapse of BHS under the Company Directors Disqualification Act 1986. <ref name="The Independent 23 March 2018">{{cite news | last= Morrison |first= Caitlan|title= Ex-BHS owner Dominic Chappell banned from running companies for 15 years |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/ex-bhs-owner-dominic-chappell-banned-philip-green-collapse-retailer-a8276031.html | date= 23 March 2018| work= [[The Independent]] }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Paul Alexander Sutton]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Chappell, Dominic}} [[Category:1966 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People educated at Millfield]] [[Category:British racing drivers]] [[Category:24 Hours of Le Mans drivers]] [[Category:International Formula 3000 drivers]] [[Category:British businesspeople]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox Officeholder |honorific-prefix = '''[[The Honourable]]''' |name = Edward Forrest |honorific-suffix = |image = Edward Barrow Forrest, 1907.jpg |caption = Edward Barrow Forrest, 1907
| constituency_AM1 = [[Electoral district of Brisbane North|Brisbane North]] | assembly1 = Queensland Legislative | term_start1 = 20 April 1899 | term_end1 = 27 April 1912 | predecessor1 = [[Robert Fraser (politician)|Robert Fraser]] | successor1 = Seat Abolished | alongside1 = [[Thomas MacDonald-Paterson]], [[John Cameron (Queensland politician, born 1845)|John Cameron]], [[Edward Barton (politician)|Edward Barton]], [[Edward Macartney]], [[Thomas Welsby]]
| office2 = [[Queensland Legislative Council|Member of the Queensland Legislative Council]] | term_start2 = 15 August 1882 | term_end2 = 8 March 1899 | term_start3 = 14 June 1913 | term_end3 = 30 March 1914
|birth_date = February 1838 |birth_place = [[Windermere, Cumbria (town)|Windemere]], [[Westmorland]], [[England]] |death_date = 30 March 1914 (aged 76) |death_place = [[Brisbane]], [[Queensland]], [[Australia]] |restingplace = [[Toowong Cemetery]] |birthname = Edward Barrow Forrest |nationality = [[England|English]] |party = Ministerial |otherparty = Opposition |spouse = Elizabeth Leary | occupation = [[Businessman]], [[Vice consul|Vice consul for France]] | relations = | religion = [[Church of England]] }}
'''Edward Barrow Forrest''' (February 1838 – 30 March 1914) was an Australian company director and politician, a member of the [[Queensland Legislative Council]] and the [[Queensland Legislative Assembly]].<ref name=adb> {{Australian Dictionary of Biography |last=Crouchley, Betty |first=Gibbney, H. J. |title=Forrest, Edward Barrow (1838–1914) |id2=forrest-edward-barrow-6209 |accessdate=18 December 2013}}</ref>
== Early life == Forrest was born in [[Windermere, Cumbria (town)|Windermere]], [[Westmorland]], England.<ref name="adb" /> He was brought to Sydney in 1852 where educated by his uncle Rev. William Forrest at [[The King's School, Parramatta|The King's School]], [[Parramatta]], [[New South Wales]].<ref name=":0">{{cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article174274105|title=Hon. E. B. Forrest.|date=31 March 1914|newspaper=[[The Telegraph (Brisbane)|The Telegraph]]|issue=12905|location=Queensland, Australia|page=8 (SECOND EDITION)|via=National Library of Australia|accessdate=14 December 2016}}</ref>
== Business interests == Forrest's first position was with the [[Colonial Sugar Refining Co.|Colonial Sugar Refining Company]], with which he remained connected throughout most of his life, being for many years their Queensland director. In 1872 he came to Brisbane to work for the firm of Parbury, Lamb & Co., rising to be managing partner in [[Queensland]]. He was a director of the [[Australian Mutual Provident Society|Australia Mutual Permanent Society]], [[Brisbane Gas Company]], the Imperial Insurance Company, the Queensland Investment Company, the North British and Mercantile Insurance Company, the [[Castlemaine Perkins|Castlemaine Brewery]], the Federal Bank and Building Society, and Quinlan, Gray and Co Limited.<ref name=":0" />
== Politics == Forrest was appointed to the Queensland Legislative Council, being sworn in on 15 August 1882. Subsequently, he was appointed one of the commissioners to inquire into the working of the Colonial Stores Office.<ref>{{cite Australasia|Forrest, Hon. Edward Barrow}}</ref>
Forrest resigned from the Legislative Council on 8 March 1899 and represented [[Electoral district of Brisbane North|Brisbane North]] in the Legislative Assembly from 20 April 1899 to 27 April 1912; he was again a member of the Legislative Council from 14 June 1913 until his death on 30 March 1914.<ref>{{cite web |title=Alphabetical Register of Members of the Legislative Assembly 1860-2012 |publisher=Queensland Parliament |url=http://www.parliament.qld.gov.au/documents/explore/parliamentaryrecord/sections/Part%202.19.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131031204133/http://www.parliament.qld.gov.au/documents/explore/parliamentaryrecord/sections/Part%202.19.pdf |archivedate=31 October 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref>
Forrest was appointed the Vice-Consul for France in 1872, an appointment he held until shortly before his death.<ref name=":0" />
== Personal life == Forrest was a keen yachtsman and the owner of the ''Isabel'', the fastest yacht in Queensland waters. He was vice-commodore of the [[Brisbane Sailing Club]]. He was one of the founders of the [[Queensland Yacht Club]] of which he was president for many years.<ref name=":0" />
On 29 April 1861, Forrest married Elizabeth Mary Leary at [[St Mary's Cathedral, Sydney|St Mary's Roman Catholic Cathedral]] and at St Paul's Church of England in Cleveland Street, [[Redfern, New South Wales|Redfern]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article4598899|title=Family Notices|date=14 May 1861|newspaper=[[The Courier (Brisbane)]]|issue=1021|location=Queensland, Australia|volume=XV,|page=6|via=National Library of Australia|accessdate=14 December 2016}}</ref> The couple had eight children.<ref name=":0" />
Forrest died in St Helen's Private Hospital in Brisbane on Monday 30 March 1914 following an illness of several months. At his request, Forrest was buried in a private ceremoney at [[Toowong Cemetery]].<ref name=":0" /><ref>[https://online.brisbane.qld.gov.au/cemeteries/cemeteries_step3.jsp?mapdisplay=193294 Forrest Edward Barrow] — Brisbane City Council Grave Location Search Retrieved 27 December 2013.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == *{{Commons category-inline|Edward Barrow Forrest}}
{{s-start}} {{s-par|au-qld}} {{s-bef|before=[[Robert Fraser (politician)|Robert Fraser]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Member for [[Electoral district of Brisbane North|Brisbane North]]|years=1899–1912|alongside=[[Thomas MacDonald-Paterson]], [[John Cameron (Queensland politician, born 1845)|John Cameron]], [[Edward Barton (politician)|Edward Barton]], [[Edward Macartney]], [[Thomas Welsby]]}} {{s-non|reason=Abolished}} {{s-end}}

revision.text:
{{Other people|Edward Boyd}} [[File:Edward F. Boyd.jpg|thumb|Edward F. Boyd (1914-2007)]] '''Edward Francis "Ed" Boyd''' (June 27, 1914 – April 30, 2007) was an American business executive who was responsible for the marketing of products specifically to [[African American]]s in an era when [[racial discrimination]] was rampant and blacks had either been ridiculed or systematically ignored in [[advertising]].<ref name="nyt">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/06/business/06boyd.html?_r=1&ref=obituaries&oref=slogin | author=[[Douglas Martin (journalist)|Douglas Martin]] | date=May 6, 2007 | title=Edward F. Boyd Dies at 92; Marketed Pepsi to Blacks.| publisher=[[The New York Times]] | accessdate=2007-05-05}}</ref> His efforts for [[Pepsi-Cola]] pioneered the concept of [[niche market]]ing and allowed Pepsi to substantially increase its [[market share]] in the black community at the expense of [[Coca-Cola]].<ref name="lat">{{cite news | url=http://www.latimes.com/news/obituaries/la-me-boyd5may05,0,7240282,full.story?coll=la-news-obituaries | title=Edward Boyd, 92; Pepsi ad man broke color barriers | publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] | first=Jocelyn Y | last=Stewart | date=May 5, 2007 | accessdate=2007-05-05}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Boyd was a leader in the [[African-American businesses|African-American business community]].
==Early life== Boyd, an African American himself, was born and grew up in [[Riverside, California]]. After high school, he trained at a local [[opera]] company and wanted to be a [[diplomat]]. After graduating from the [[University of California, Los Angeles]] in 1938, he enjoyed a short film career, playing minor roles, often as stereotypical singing and dancing roles which he resented.<ref name="nyt"/> During his time in [[Hollywood]], he escorted [[Hattie McDaniel]] to the 1939 [[Academy Award]]s ceremony when she became the first African American performer to win the prestigious award.<ref name="smiley">{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/kcet/tavissmiley/archive/200702/20070227_boyd.html |first=Smiley |last=Tavis |date=February 27, 2007 |title=Edward Boyd |publisher=[[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] |format=interview |accessdate=2007-05-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929205458/http://www.pbs.org/kcet/tavissmiley/archive/200702/20070227_boyd.html |archivedate=September 29, 2007 }}</ref> He later worked for the [[Screen Actors Guild]], was the first African American to work for the [[Civil Service Commission]] in [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]],<ref name="lat"/> and then worked as a housing specialist for the [[National Urban League]].
==Career at Pepsi== [[Image:Pepsi targeted ad 1940s.jpg|thumb|Boyd's advertisement for Pepsi. The young boy is [[Ron Brown (U.S. politician)|Ron Brown]].]] When Boyd joined Pepsi in 1947, most U.S. businesses either ignored the African American market or depicted them using ethnic stereotypes such as the "[[Mammy archetype]]".<ref name="lat"/> But [[Walter Staunton Mack Jr.|Walter S. Mack]], president of Pepsi at the time, saw the potential of a vast untapped market.<ref name="nyt"/> In fact, he had previously established an all-black sales team in 1940, but had to drop it due to the onset of [[World War II]].
Boyd's idea, revolutionary at the time, was to create advertisements that showed black Americans as normal, middle-class people. One such ad featured a smiling mother holding a [[six pack rings|six pack]] of Pepsi while her son (a young [[Ron Brown (U.S. politician)|Ron Brown]], who grew up to be [[United States Secretary of Commerce|Secretary of Commerce]]<ref name="lat"/>) reaches up for one. Another [[ad campaign]], titled "Leaders in Their Fields", profiled twenty prominent African Americans such as [[Nobel Peace Prize]] winner [[Ralph Bunche]].
Boyd also led a sales team composed entirely of African Americans around the country to promote Pepsi. [[Racial segregation in the United States|Racial segregation]] and [[Jim Crow laws]] were still in place throughout much of the U.S. and Boyd's team encountered a great deal of discrimination.<ref name="nyt"/> Not only did they have to ride on segregated trains and stay in black-only hotels, but they faced insults from Pepsi co-workers and even endured threats from the [[Ku Klux Klan]].<ref name="lat"/> On the other hand, they were able to use [[racism]] as a selling point, attacking Coke's reluctance to hire blacks and the support of segregationist [[Governor of Georgia]] [[Herman Talmadge]] by the chairman of Coke.<ref name="nyt"/> As a result, Pepsi's market share (as compared to Coke's) shot up dramatically. After the sales team visited [[Chicago]], Pepsi's share in the city overtook that of Coke for the first time.<ref name="nyt"/>
This focus on the African American market caused some consternation within the company and among its affiliates. They did not want to seem focused on black customers for fear that [[whites]] would be pushed away.<ref name="nyt"/> In a meeting at the [[Waldorf-Astoria Hotel]], Pepsico president Mack, who favored progressive causes and was the impetus for this marketing push, tried to assuage the 500 [[bottling company|bottlers]] in attendance by saying, "We don't want it to become known as the [[nigger]] drink."<ref name="smiley"/> Boyd understood that those were not Mack's sentiments. "I didn't forget it, but I didn't hold it against him either," he told the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]''.<ref name="lat"/> After Mack left the company in 1950, support for the black sales team faded and Boyd was let go.
''Wall Street Journal'' writer Stephanie Capparell argues in her book ''The Real Pepsi Challenge'' that Boyd faced a more difficult challenge than [[Jackie Robinson]] in breaking the color barrier of corporate America. By doing the same work and competing for the same jobs as white people, Boyd's team presented more of a threat to the average white man.<ref name="usatoday">{{cite news | url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/books/reviews/2007-01-22-pepsi-book_x.htm?csp=34 | title=Pepsi's challenge in 1940s: Color barrier | publisher=[[USA Today]] | first=Michelle | last=Archer | date=January 22, 2007 | accessdate=2007-05-07}}</ref>
==Later life== There were few opportunities for a black man as a business executive at that time, but Boyd's career continued over a variety of public and private sector jobs. He was a mission chief for [[CARE (relief)|CARE]], worked with the [[Society of Ethical Culture]], and helped to pioneer [[alpaca]] farming in the U.S.<ref name="lat"/>
Boyd's sister, Helen Boyd Howard, was married to Dr. [[T.R.M. Howard]], a surgeon, entrepreneur, and civil rights leader in Mississippi who was a mentor to [[Medgar Evers]] and [[Fannie Lou Hamer]].<ref>David T. Beito and Linda Royster Beito, ''Black Maverick: T.R.M. Howard's Fight for Civil Rights and Economic Power'' (Urbana: University of Illinois Press, 2009), 75, 79 83.</ref>
Boyd died in [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]] due to various complications including a [[stroke]] he had suffered nearly two months earlier. ==See also== * [[African-American businesses]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite book | title=The Real Pepsi Challenge: The Inspirational Story of Breaking the Color Barrier in American Business | first=Stephanie | last=Capparell | publisher=Free Press | year=2007 | isbn=0743265718}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Boyd, Edward F.}} [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:People from Riverside, California]] [[Category:1914 births]] [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:American marketing people]]
